batch¶

class batch.BatchBuffer(pipe_name, batch_size, overlap=False)[source]¶

For reading and buffering a stream of input data. For use with non-state swapping LSTM code.

Parameters:
  • pipe_name – Name of pipe to read from
  • batch_size – Number of time steps to send
Returns:

A BatchBuffer object that reads from the named pipe
next_no_overlap_window()[source]¶
Returns:Next batch_size time steps from data stream
next_overlap_window()[source]¶
class batch.NewStateTrackingBatcher(pipe_name, specs, batchsize=21, num_steps=3, layers=10, replay_period=0, next_step=False, warm_start_state=None, verbose=False)[source]¶

Reads line by line from a pipe being fed csv format features by a feature extractor. Keeps track of window of user history for truncated backpropagation through time with shifting set of users.

Parameters:
  • pipe_name – Pipe to read from
  • specs – Path to a json file describing the delimitation of features in the csv line.
  • batchsize – The maximum number of events in a mini-batch
  • num_steps – The maximum number of events for any given user per mini-batch (window size sort of)
  • layers – A list of the sizes of hidden layers for the stacked lstm.
  • replay_period – 0 if not using replay. Otherwise get a new batch every replay period times.
  • next_step – 0 if autoencoding, 1 if next time step prediction
  • verbose – 0 if not printing, 1 if progress printing, 2 if debug printing
avg_state()[source]¶
Returns:The average of all the most recent states for each batch entity.
blank_slate()[source]¶

Creates and returns a zero state for one time step for 1 user :return: A list of 1 X state_size numpy arrays the number of layers long

event_padding(user, length)[source]¶

Creates and returns a “non-event” for event history padding of newly encountered user. :param user: integer id for user :param length: size of feature space :return:

get_new_events()[source]¶

To got new events when not replaying old events.

next_batch()[source]¶
Returns:A dictionary with keys to match to placeholders and values of numpy matrices. ‘states’: A structured list of numpy arrays to feed as initial state for next round of training ‘inputs: A three way numpy array of dimensions (timestep X user X (feature_size + target_size + meta_size))
where meta-size is the number of fields not used in training (user_id, timestamp, etc.)
‘eval_indices’: A num_time_steps long list of numpy vectors which contain the indices of hidden state
outputs to evaluate on for each time step in this batch of training.

Other entries are split from the ‘inputs’ matrix using the specs dictionary which describes indices of matrices to extract.
next_batch_report()[source]¶
package_data(batch)[source]¶
Parameters:batch – An assembled 3 way array of data collected from the stream with shape (num_time_steps, num_users, num_features)
Returns:A dictionary of numpy arrays of the diced 3way feature array.
update_states(states)[source]¶

For updating the deque of lstm states for each user after a minibatch of training. :param states: The unstructured list of state matrices evaluated after a train step.

update_states_report(last_states, statelist, user_state_list)[source]¶
batch.derive_cert_features(stream_name, pipe_name)[source]¶

Place holder for feature derivation function :param stream_name: Where data is coming from (in this case it is a file. Could be a socket or pipe) :param pipe_name: Whatever the pipe is called

batch.derive_toy_lanl_features(datafile, pipe_name)[source]¶
Stream data from the source, do necessary processing, and feature extraction.
Write each piece of processed data to a pipe. For mocking streaming.
Parameters:
  • datafile – Data source. Treat this as a stream.
  • pipe_name – The name of the pipe to write the processed feature vectors to.
